content.description:
Start on the outside corner and drift to the left as you go up. Surmount the overhang staying left of the corner and then climb up to easy finishing ledges near the top.

 Easy climbing for the first 2/3 of the climb except for the 4" diameter tree that gets in your way, then a couple 5.7 moves, followed by more easy climbing near the top.

 This is unnamed route #16 in Swartling/Mayer and unnamed #2 in Knower.
content.location: The walls on the right side of the buttress zig and zag a couple times to create 2 outside corners.This is the right-most corner.

content.description:
Start on the thin face a few feet right of the outside corner. Climb more or less straight up staying right of the outside corner.

 This climb is more enjoyable and with more sustained 5.7 difficulty than it's neighbor to the left, Vulture Terrace.

 This is a named climb in both Swartling/Mayer and Knower.
content.location: Just right of the right-most outside corner of the buttress.

content.description:
Climb the center of the south-facing wall right of the chimney and left of the outside corner.

 This is unnamed route #13 in Swartling/Mayer. Not mentioned in Knower.
content.location: On the right side of the buttress between Right Turkey Foot and Dove Tail.

content.description: A clean, easy chimney, that chokes off 2/3 of the way to the top.  The crux is right where you think it is, and more awkward than it even looks.  A one-move climb.

Climb the corner and face left of Squeeze Play. 

  A harder variation (5.10a) starts out on the face and only uses the corner higher up - not too contrived.
content.protection: None until it is too late.

content.description: Chimney just right of American Dream Roof.
Typical D.L. face, very thin and very techinal, (fun) climbs face, starts with some good holds for a couple of moves, then it gets thin,
content.location: Between Squeeze play and Mother and Apple Pie

content.description: Route #3 in the guidebook for Bird-foot Buttress. A mediocre face that is slightly more fun than it appears. The guidebook rates it at 5.7 but it gets much easier if you are somewhat tall.
content.protection: Standard rack should be fine, but probably too short for anything but TR
content.location: The face the forms the right wall of Left Turkey Foot (#2 in guidebook).

content.description: Use the crack as much as possible, liebacking to the left.  Ignore the guidebook and use the corner where it feels natural to grab it.
content.protection: Almost, but not quite enough to keep you from hitting the ground.
content.location: Right hand edge of the face to the right of Squeeze Play.  Around the corner to the left of American Dream Roof.

content.description: Climb the left corner of the face
content.location: Left edge of the face left of Squeeze Play

content.description: Chimney at the left end of the crag
Starting with blocky jugs, climb corner to a fun mantle and a few slopey moves below the finish.
content.location: Corner just right of Mother and Apple Pie.

climbs.name: Face Value
climbs.fa: FTR: Joel and Dan?  FL: Eggert?

content.description: Starts with a desperate crimpy boulder problem to a horizontal around 16+ feet off the ground.  From here, go more or less straight up the face with heroic moves on jugs and edges.  We did not use the right arete.
content.protection: TR or decent pro in the horizontals.
content.location: Climb the face between the "Sick Vulture" and "Little Bird" aretes.

content.description:
Start up the blocks near the corner, head up the slightly overhanging wall right of the corner on great edges.  There are two variations, up the center, and veering slightly right.  A long reach helps.

 Each variation consists of 3-4 moves.  Nice while they last!
content.protection: This would NOT be a good lead - more of a solo with gear.
content.location: In between Hard Nose and American Dream Roof.

content.description:
Climb the outside corner about 10' right of the chimney. There are 2 ways to climb it.

 The first is to stay more or less on the corner most of the way up (named Dove Tail Left in Swartling/Mayer).

 The second is to climb primarily using the hand/fist crack just around the right of the corner. This 2nd option is very enjoyable but the difficulty goes down to 5.6 (named Dove Tail Right in Swartling/Mayer).
content.location: The walls on the right side of the buttress zig and zag a couple times to create 2 outside corners. This is the left-most corner and closest to the Right Turkey Foot chimney.

climbs.name: American Dream Roof
climbs.fa: Rich Bechler and some DLFA losers circa 1982

content.description:
There was a photo of American Dream Roof that hung above the bar at the now-defunct Conway's Pub. Inspired by the photo, many beer addled climbers hatched plans to hike out and climb ADR only to see those plans evaporate when the hangover set in. If you do make it out there, ADR is a must-do DL lead.   

  American Dream Roof climbs the conspicuous overhang on the right side of the buttress. Start up the easy inside corner and traverse to the roof. From here, place your entire rack of cams under the roof (when I first led it, I placed 5 cams) and climb, using dynamic moves, to the top.  

  Though it is possible to stop and place gear above the roof, I thought it added too much difficulty to be worth it, but make your own call.  ADR is basically a boulder problem protected by a bunch of gear that you put in from a great stance; therefore, it may be the easiest 5.10 lead at DL.

Climb only the left wall of the Left Turkey Foot chimney. The overhanging wall and narrow crack make for a challenging climb.

 This is a named climb in the Swartling/Mayer book at 5.9, and also mentioned in the Knower book as a 5.9 variation of Left Turkey Foot.
content.location: located in the left-most climbable part of the Bird Foot Buttress, and left of Left Turkey Foot.

pathTokens: East Bluff 03 - West of the Quarry

content.description: High in the woods west of the Quarry, this is probably the best known outcrop in the area, largely because the American Dream Roof is such an unusual problem for the Lake.  There are several other nice, moderate routes around the corner to the left.  However the descriptions given in Swarting veer toward the contrived (i.e. "avoid using the lower right corner"), which I find aesthetically unsatisfying (I guess I'm more of a mountaineer than a boulderer).  If you are willing to ignore the rules, there are at least 4-5 fun routes here.
